content: You should probably mention that there always exists a solution for the given testcases and that we want d digits without leading 0s.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle, lucrative to solve.

Please remove the test case: "That huge number". I hate it when a clash goes out of its way just to push the limits of what a language is capable of handling natively. I can pass the validator and not the test case itself. Which will lead to one of those instances where you don't pass 100% of the tests when testing, yet you will pass 100% when you submit.

Moreover, if the programmer decides to fix it (which in C++ would be done by using a string instead of an int), then that just takes time and can easily lose a fastest mode. Anyone who decides to first code this using numbers instead of strings with, let's say, C#, would instantly have the advantage since they'd pass all the tests with "decimal".

Otherwise, it's a very good problem.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: a bit hard but not for  CG :D

"number of digits d" would be better than "amount of digits d" (amount is used for things which cannot be counted)

First constraint should be "1 <= d <= 20", not "1 <= n <= 20

That test could be changed to something like "19 98" or validator to "20 100".

I don't think there is the problem with fast mode - in most clashes you could write a solution that that does not pass certain test cases and then rewrite it.
Also, this clash was planned as string manipulation problem from the beginning and my initial pre-published version had  1<=d<=100.

I'm only asking to make those numbers a tad smaller. My code passed the validator and not the original test. One of the things about a clash is that every person will code it differently, so making it that huge is only restrictive. Make the actual test something like "19 97" so that it's different yet still within 64 bits.
Ok, constraints and validators changed to fit signed 64 bit variable.
